Skeleton state and final content.
Skeletons should be as close as possible to the
dimensions of the final content
Skeletons are placeholders that must be adapted to each scenario to represent
headings, media or body text.
It is important that the size of the Skeleton is consistent with the content that is being
loaded so there is no layout shift when the actual content fills the space.

Skeleton state and final state.
Use Skeletons when dynamically loading content
A Skeleton can be used while loading dynamic content, that is, loaded after the
interface is first painted. Interactive components and static content that are server-side
rendered do not need a Skeleton.

Skeletons are used to display dynamic content while static content are displayed right away.
Display the final content as soon as it is loaded
Skeletons create the feel of shorter wait times, loading content progressively and
displaying content as fast as possible.
Display each piece of content as soon as it's available, regardless of whether other
items are still loading. Do not wait to show all loaded content together.

Skeleton vs. Loading
Skeleton and Loading both represent loading states.
Skeletons represent the shapes of specific elements that will be loaded and they load
progressively without blocking interactions or causing layout shifts.
The Loading component communicates wait time without illustrating what comes next
and can display a label and progress ratio.

Skeleton Loading
Do not use Skeleton and Loading together
The Skeleton placeholder itself acts as a loading indicator, so it is not necessary to add
additional loading indicators. Use the most appropriate indicator to show loading
progress for your application. Use Skeleton or Loading, but not both.

Motion
Skeleton state animation
Skeletons are presented on the page right away and should be replaced with final
content as fast as possible. The Skeleton itself has a subtle animated gradient that
fades horizontally from left to right.
